metadata.title: Pd/DNA as a highly active and recyclable catalyst for aminocarbonylation and hydroxycarbonylation in water: The effect of Mo(CO)<ce:inf loc=post>6</ce:inf> on the reaction course

Scheme 1 Aminocarbonylation of aryl iodides with anilines. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene with diphenylamine. Scheme 2 Scheme 3 Hydroxycarbonylation of iodobenzenes. Scheme 3 Scheme 4 Aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene with hexylamine. Scheme 4 Scheme 5 Aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene with hexylamine and two CO sources. Scheme 5 Scheme 6 Aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene with aliphatic amines. Scheme 6 Fig. 1 Pd 3d core level spectra for Pd(OAc)2 as reference (a), Pd/DNA (b). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 N 1s core level spectra for the DNA surface (as reference) (a), Pd/DNA (b). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 P 2p core level spectra for the DNA surface (as reference) (a), Pd/DNA (b). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Morphology and size distribution of Pd/DNA. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XRD patterns of Pd/DNA. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Recycling of Pd/DNA in the aminocarbonylation reaction. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Pd 3d core level spectra for Pd/DNA recovered after the aminocarbonylation reaction ‘as received’ (a) and after smooth Ar+ sputtering (500 eV, 1 min, 0.2 μA/cm2 + 1 keV, 1 min, 1.3 μA/cm2) (b). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 XRD pattern of Pd/DNA recovered after the aminocarbonylation reaction. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 TEM images of Pd/DNA after five catalytic runs and particle size distribution. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The SEM image and the EDX spectrum of Pd/DNA after aminocarbonylation with W(CO)6. Pd/W: 1–7.3, 2–7.8, 3–5.6, 4–7.2, 5–6.7, 6–7.6. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Plausible reaction mechanism. Pd/DNA as a highly active and recyclable catalyst for aminocarbonylation and hydroxycarbonylation in water: The effect of Mo(CO)6 on the reaction course M. Mart a W. Tylus b A.M. Trzeciak a ⁎ a University of Wrocław, Faculty of Chemistry, 14 F. Joliot-Curie, 50-383 Wrocław, Poland University of Wrocław Faculty of Chemistry 14 F. Joliot-Curie Wrocław 50-383 Poland b Wroclaw University of Technology, Institute of Inorganic Technology, Wybrzeże Wyspiańskiego 27, 50-370 Wroclaw, Poland Wroclaw University of Technology Institute of Inorganic Technology Wybrzeże Wyspiańskiego 27 Wroclaw 50-370 Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A Pd/DNA catalyst was prepared using Pd(OAc)2 and salmon fish sperm DNA in a H2O/EtOH solution. This catalyst contained Pd(II) coordinated to DNA and ca. 20% of Pd(0) nanoparticles. For the first time, Pd/DNA was applied with very good results in the aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene with different amines in water at 1 atm of CO and with Mo(CO)6 as a CO source. During the catalytic process, Pd(II) was reduced to catalytically active Pd(0), as evidenced by XPS. The aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene with n-hexylamine performed with Mo(CO)6 proceeded with better selectivity than with gaseous CO. Very good results were also obtained with other primary amines, while secondary amines gave a lower yield of the relevant amides. The recovered Pd/DNA catalyst was used in four subsequent runs with high activity. Keywords Palladium Nanoparticles DNA Aminocarbonylation 1 Introduction Palladium-catalyzed coupling reactions offer efficient and simple procedures leading to important aryl compounds, such as acids, amides, ketones, or biaryls [1–5]. Amides are common structural motifs found in many natural products, pharmaceuticals, and agrochemicals [6]. Although palladium is a metal of choice in carbonylative coupling reactions due to its very high efficiency, searching for new palladium catalysts is still a challenge. Not only complexes but also palladium nanoparticles (Pd NPs) should be taken into account [7–11]. Special advantages can be offered by palladium immobilization on the support. The most important one is the possibility of the efficient separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture and its reuse without activity loss. As a result, organic products do not contain metal impurities, which is very important for their further applications in the pharmaceutical industry. Moreover, due to the efficient recycling of the catalyst, the overall cost of the process can be decreased. In the case of Pd NPs, the support can play an additional role of a stabilizing agent preventing nanoparticle agglomeration and, in consequence, activity reduction. Different polymers have been used for this purpose; however, only a few reports have concerned the application of DNA. DNA is a non-toxic biopolymer with many unique features, including chirality [12]. The rich functionalization of DNA with different groups has made it possible to consider it a good ligand for metal ions and metal nanoparticles [13–16]. However, metal and metal-oxide nanoparticle templates on DNA have only scarcely been employed in catalysis. DNA-mediated Pd NPs have been tested in the Suzuki–Miyaura coupling reaction by Hori et al., but low efficiency has been achieved with bromobenzene derivatives [17]. DNA-based asymmetric catalysis with the introduction of a new artificial enzyme consisting of platinum and a nucleotide polymer has been carried out [18–21]. A highly selective imination catalyzed by Pd/DNA in water has been reported [22]. Recently, DNA-supported Pd NPs have been successfully used in copper, amine, and ligand-free Sonogashira reactions [23]. Palladium-catalyzed aminocarbonylation is an important tool for amide synthesis. Heck reported the first example of aminocarbonylation reactions of aryl heterocyclic and vinylic halides with primary or secondary amines [24]. Afterwards, various catalytic systems have been tested for aminocarbonylation [25–40]. During the last decade Pd NPs have widely been used for aminocarbonylation reaction [41–49]. In these studies, Pd NPs have been supported on carbon nanotubes, polymers, MOF-5, ZIF-8, and on binaphthyl. Our studies aimed at the synthesis of a DNA-supported palladium catalyst and its application, for the first time, in the aminocarbonylation reaction. It was expected that Pd/DNA would be active in a water medium without any organic solvent. By selecting Pd/DNA for our studies, we also expected to gain new knowledge about the influence of the DNA support on the reaction course. It was interesting to learn whether any synergistic effect could be achieved by combining palladium and DNA as a special template. 2 Experimental All chemicals were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Fish sperm DNA (CAS:438545-06-3) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (price: 145 €/gram). 2.1 Preparation of Pd/DNA 50 mg of fish sperm DNA was dissolved in 5 mL of water. Then, 112 mg of Pd(OAc)2 and 5 mL of ethanol were added in turn. The combined solution was stirred for 24 h at room temperature. During the reaction, the mixture changed in color from brown to black. Then with the aid of centrifugation at 7000 r/min, Pd/DNA was precipitated. The clear solution was poured out, and Pd/DNA was washed with acetone and dried in vacuo. Pd/DNA was obtained as a dark powder. (Pd target loading estimated by ICP: 3.56 mmol/g) 2.2 General procedure for the aminocarbonylation reaction In a typical reaction, a 50 mL Schlenk flask was charged with iodobenzene (1 mmol), amine derivative (1.2 mmol), NEt3 (3 mmol), and the Pd/DNA catalyst (containing 0.01 mmol of Pd). Then, 3 mL of the solvent was added. Under the balloon pressure of CO, the resulting mixture was stirred for 6 h at 80 °C. After that time, the Schlenk flask was cooled down, the organic products were extracted with 3 × 7 mL of diethyl ether. The extracts were GC-FID analyzed with mesitylene (0.076 mL) as an internal standard. After the solvent was evaporated, the crude product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel. The corresponding products were characterized by GC–MS, 1H NMR and 13C NMR. 2.3 General procedure for Mo(CO)6-mediated aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene In a typical reaction, a 50 mL Schlenk flask was charged with iodobenzene (1 mmol), Mo(CO)6 (0.25 mmol), aliphatic amine (3 mmol), NEt3 (3 mmol), and the Pd/DNA catalyst (containing 0.01 mmol of Pd). Then, 3 mL of H2O was added. The resulting mixture was stirred for 3–6 h at 50–80 °C. After that time, the Schlenk flask was cooled down, the organic products were extracted with 3 × 7 mL of diethyl ether. The extracts were GC-FID analyzed with mesitylene (0.076 mL) as an internal standard. After the solvent was evaporated, the crude product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel. The corresponding products were characterized by GC–MS, 1H NMR and 13C NMR. 2.4 General procedure for Pd/DNA recycling After the first run, the Schlenk flask was cooled down and the organic products were extracted with 3 × 7 mL of diethyl ether. Then by the aid of centrifugation at 7000 r/min the catalyst was precipitated. The clear solution was then poured out by direct decantation, and the catalyst was washed with acetone and dried in vacuo. The dried catalyst was used for the next run in order to test its recyclability. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure of Pd/DNA A Pd/DNA catalyst was prepared using Pd(OAc)2 and salmon fish sperm DNA in a H2O/EtOH solution. The XPS analysis of Pd/DNA showed Pd 3d spectra (Fig. 1 ) characterized by the typical two spin-orbit components, Pd (3d5 / 2) and Pd (3d3/2),separated by approximately 5.4 eV. Fig. 1b shows a Pd 3d line deconvoluted into two doublets attributed to two different chemical species, Pd(0) and Pd(II). The first peak, centered at 335.5 ± 0.1 eV (3d5/2), corresponded to Pd(0) [50]. The second peak, centered at 338.2 eV (3d5/2), corresponded to Pd(II) with binding energy exactly the same as in the primary form of palladium in Pd(OAc)2 (Fig. 1a).The calculated content of Pd(0) present in the Pd/DNA was 20%. Figs. 2 and 3 present the N 1 s and P 2p spectra of Pd/DNA. The binding energies, BE 132.89 eV and BE 133.74 eV, were attributed to P 2p3/2 and P 2p1/2, respectively. These values are characteristic of PO4 3− in DNA. Similarly, the N 1 s peak at 399.32 eV was assigned to the NC bond in DNA. In both cases, the N 1 s and P 2p signals, small chemical changes of BE values relative to pure DNA were observed after the introduction of Pd (Figs. 2 and 3). The observed shifts of Pd/DNA peaks to higher binding energy values were estimated for Pd/DNA and amounted to 0.3 eV for N 1s and 0.2 eV for P 2p. The observed changes in XPS spectra indicated the coordination of palladium to the PO2 − group of DNA and the nitrogen atom that belongs to the base pairs of DNA. These assumptions were supported by FT-IR studies [22]. A comparison of the FT-IR spectra of pure DNA with Pd/DNA indicated some differences. Thus, symmetric and asymmetric stretching peaks of PO4 3− observed in pure DNA at 1062 and 1259 cm−1 were weakened for Pd/DNA and shifted to 1050 and 1208 cm−1. In addition, changes were observed in the 1627–1641 cm−1 region, assigned to ν(CC), ν(CN), and ν(CO), as well as the weakening of the ν(CN) band at1482 cm−1 (see Fig. ESI-1). The changes in the region of PO2 − and the nitrogen group of DNA indicated their involvement in palladium bonding. During coordination, these groups substituted OAc- ligands in Pd(OAc)2 as it was evidenced by the absence of ν(COO−) bands at 1569 cm−1and 1410 cm−1 in the Pd/DNA spectrum. TEM studies were carried out to get deeper insight into characteristics of the Pd/DNA. A wide range of nanoparticle sizes (3–25 nm) was observed with a maximum of ca. 13–15 nm, together with some aggregates (Fig. 4 ). These results showed that Pd/DNA contained Pd(0) in the form of nanoparticles. The crystalline structure of Pd NPs was checked by the XRD method. A typical diffractogram revealed several well-defined peaks attributed to Pd(0) crystallizing in the Fm3m space group (JCPDS card number 5–681). The broadening of the diffraction lines indicated a small size of Pd NPs (Fig. 5 ). 3.2 Aminocarbonylation reactions of aryl iodides with anilines The catalytic performance of Pd/DNA was tested in the aminocarbonylation of aryl iodides with aniline derivatives in water under the balloon pressure of CO (Scheme 1 , Table 1 ). This aminocarbonylation reaction was effective with electron-rich and electron-deficient aniline derivatives, which were converted efficiently into the desired amides in excellent yields (Table 1, 1a–1e). In reactions carried out with 4-iodotoluene and 1-iodonaphthalene, modest yields were obtained (Table 1, 1f and 1g). Under the applied conditions, Pd/DNA showed better catalytic activity than commercially available Pd/C (Table 1, 1a). The aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene with aniline was also performed using metal carbonyls, Mo(CO)6,W(CO)6 and Co2(CO)8, as a CO source (Table 2 ). Such a method simplified the experimental procedure and made it possible to avoid a gaseous reactant [51–53]. Considering reactions conducted with metal carbonyls only with Mo(CO)6, amide 1a was formed; however, its yield was 11% lower than that with gaseous CO (Table 2, run 4). 3.3 Catalyst recycling in aminocarbonylation reaction One of the desirable characteristics of supported catalysts is their recycling potential [54]. It means they preserve their catalytic activity and remain stable even when they have been used several times. The recycling potential of Pd/DNA was therefore investigated in the aminocarbonylation reaction. For this purpose, a reaction was carried out between iodobenzene and aniline with 1 mol% of Pd. At the end of the catalytic reaction, the organic products were separated by extraction, and the catalyst was recovered for the next run by simple centrifugation. After the first run, the palladium content in the reaction solution was determined by ICP-MS as 0.018 wt% of the original amount. However, the Pd/DNA showed good reusability in aminocarbonylation for at least four runs (Fig. 6 ). It should be noted however that reliable data on the retaining catalytic activity can not be provided at the moment. Results of kinetic studies were not reproducible due to the heterogeneity of reaction medium. Our reactions were conducted in aqueous medium, and GC or NMR analyses of small samples from the solution contained different proportions of aqueous and organic phases. The Pd/DNA catalyst recovered after aminocarbonylation was subjected to XPS, XRD and TEM analyses. Fig. 7 shows the Pd 3d spectra of the Pd/DNA catalyst surface after the aminocarbonylation reaction. The optimal fit was obtained by assuming the presence of two palladium forms. The dominant component with the binding energy of 335.2 eV for Pd (3d5/2) was assigned to Pd(0). The amount of Pd(0) was estimated as 72.2% (Fig. 6a). The remaining part of the Pd 3d spectrum was assigned to Pd(II) with peaks at the binding energy of 337.5 eV. With deconvolution, the Pd(0) peak asymmetry was taken into account [55]. The chemical shifts between Pd(0) and Pd(II) of 2.5–2.6 eV were very similar to those shown in Fig. 1. The procedure used to recover the catalyst for the XPS analysis required long-term contact with air at an elevated temperature. Hence, on the surface of the metallic palladium, PdO could also be present, in addition to carbon contaminations and oxidized carbon forms (CO, CO). To solve this problem, the grain surface of the catalyst sample was cleaned with an Ar+ beam. To prevent the possible Pd(II) photoreduction, a second series of Ar+ sputtering was performed, with very mild etching (I – 500 eV, 1 min, 0.2 μA/cm2 and II – 1 keV, 1 min, 1.3 μA/cm2). It turned out that, as a result, the contribution of Pd(0) in the sample increased to 84.1% (Fig. 7b). It was therefore evidenced that, during the catalytic process, the amount of Pd(0) increased significantly, from ca. 20% to ca. 80%. A similar effect was observed in our earlier studies on aminocarbonylation with Pd-BIAN complexes [56]. The XRD picture obtained for Pd/DNA recovered after the aminocarbonylation reaction (Fig. 8 ) was very similar to that of the as-prepared Pd/DNA (Fig. 5). It confirmed the presence of crystalline Pd(0) nanoparticles. The TEM analysis of the Pd/DNA recovered at the end of the recycling experiment showed some decrease in the average diameter of Pd NPs, with the maximum at ca. 9–10 nm (Fig. 9 ). 3.4 Aminocarbonylation reactions of iodobenzene with diphenylamine After promising experiments with aniline derivatives, we tested a Pd/DNA system with less basic diphenylamine (Scheme 2 ). Under the same conditions, in water, the yield of diphenylbenzamide was 34% (Table 3 , entry 2). When dioxane or DMF was used as a solvent, there was no conversion of iodobenzene, probably due to poor dispersion of Pd/DNA in these solvents. Unexpectedly, a high amount of benzoic acid 2b was also formed in these reactions. Its amount was lowered to 21% by the application of a higher amount of diphenylamine (Table 3, entry 3), but the contribution of competitive hydroxycarbonylation leading to benzoic acid was still significant. 3.5 Hydroxycarbonylation of aryl iodides To learn more about hydroxycarbonylation, additional experiments were performed without diphenylamine. The ability of Pd/DNA to form benzoic acids was studied using aryl iodides and both CO sources, Mo(CO)6 and gaseous CO (Scheme 3 , Table 4 ). The application of metal carbonyls instead of toxic CO presents an attractive improvement of the catalytic system. It was therefore interesting to compare the efficiency of two alternative procedures leading to benzoic acids. The reaction conducted with gaseous CO gave good yield with iodobenzene, while 4-iodotoluene was less reactive (Table 4, entries 1 and 3). When Mo(CO)6 was used as the CO source, excellent results were obtained with both iodobenzene and 4-iodotoluene (Table 4, entries 2 and 4). It is worth to note, that Pd nanoparticles supported on a DNA-MMT (MMT = montmorillonite) catalyzed oxidation of alcohols to benzoic acid [57] however their activity in hydroxycarbonylation was tested here for the first time. 3.6 Aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene with aliphatic amines After testing aminocarbonylation with aromatic amines, we also tried to optimize reaction conditions for a representative aliphatic amine, n-hexylamine. For this purpose, reactions were carried out at 80 °C and 50 °C, with gaseous CO, Mo(CO)6, or W(CO)6 (Scheme 4 , Table 5 ). In reactions conducted at 80 °C with gaseous CO, the best yield of the desired product 3a was obtained with three equivalents of n-hexylamine (Table 5, entry 4).When a lower amount of n-hexylamine was applied, the yield of 3a decreased, and other products, 3c, 3d, and 3e, emerged. Interestingly, in reactions carried out with Mo(CO)6 or with W(CO)6, 3a was obtained in higher yield than with CO even at a lower amount of amine (Table 5, entries 6 and 9). It is interesting that W(CO)6, which was not useful in reaction with aniline, gave quite good results when n-hexylamine was a substrate. A very good yield of 3a, 91%, was obtained when Mo(CO)6 was used instead of CO at 50 °C (Table 5, entry 13). The same result was obtained with Mo(CO)6 at 80 °C in the absence of the base (NEt3) (Table 5, entry 10). Considering the fact that the catalytic activity of Mo(CO)6 in palladium-free aminocarbonylation [58] and in ethylene carbonylation [59] was reported, we performed a blank experiment without Pd/DNA. However, Mo(CO)6 alone did not give any conversion (Table 5, entry 7). It can be concluded from the data presented in Table 5 that the main problem in aminocarbonylation with n-hexylamine is low selectivity. In general, aminocarbonylation with aliphatic amines is less selective than with aromatic ones [56–60]. It should therefore be underlined that the application of Mo(CO)6 instead of CO significantly improved selectivity to 3a. Excellent selectivity to 3a was achieved in the reaction of iodobenzene andn-hexylamine performed in the presence of both CO sources, Mo(CO)6 and gaseous CO (Scheme 5 ). For comparison, the same reaction carried out without Mo(CO)6 produced only 41% of the product (Table 5, entry 2). In the further step of the studies, other aliphatic amines were tested as substrates for aminocarbonylation with gaseous CO and Mo(CO)6 (Scheme 6 , Table 6 ). When Mo(CO)6 was used as a CO source, very good yields were obtained with primary amines, benzylamine and n-propyl amine (Table 6, entries 2 and 4). In reactions conducted with a secondary amine, dipropylamine, the desired product was obtained with Mo(CO)6 with a yield of 34%, while with gaseous CO(g) the yield increased to 56% (Table 6, entries 6 and 9). As for a reaction conducted with Mo(CO)6 and gaseous CO, 66% of the desired product was obtained and it was the highest yield (Table 6, entry 8). With dihexylamine, the highest yield of the desired product, 45%, was obtained with gaseous CO (Table 6, entry 13). Attempts to perform aminocarbonylation with dihexylamine in the absence of NEt3 failed, and the desired product was not obtained (Table 6, entry 14). 3.7 Effect of Mo(CO)6 and W(CO)6 Synergistic effects obtained with Mo(CO)6 and W(CO)6 in some reactions motivated us to undertake structural studies of the mixed catalysts. First, we studied the distribution of Pd and Mo or W on the surface of DNA after the aminocarbonylation reaction. Because of overlap between Pd and Mo lines in EDX, the studies were performed for Pd and W. After aminocarbonylation conducted with W(CO)6, the catalyst was separated and analyzed using the SEM/EDX method. An analysis showed that Pd and W were found at the same places on the surface of the recovered catalyst. It was observed that the amount of Pd at all of the seven points analyzed was higher than the amount of W. The Pd/W ratios calculated from the weight percentages estimated by EDX varied from 5.6 to 7.8 (Fig. 10 ). These results indicated the bonding of W to the DNA surface together with Pd. This can result in metal–metal interactions and the improvement of the catalytic process [61]. For example, the mixed Pd-Mo clusters have been characterized and applied in carbonylation of nitrobenzene [62,63]. 3.8 Treatment of Pd/DNA with Hg(0) The mercury test was performed in order to determine whether Pd nanoparticles were responsible for aminocarbonylation [64,65]. When Hg(0) was added to the catalytic system together with the substrates, no conversion was noted (Table 7 , entry 2).When Hg(0) was added after 1 h of the reaction, the yield was 66% (Table 7, entry 4). For comparison, a 1 h reaction without Hg(0) produced 55% of the product, while after 6 h, the yield was 91%. Thus, the presence of Hg(0) significantly inhibited the reaction course due to the formation of a Pd/Hg amalgam on the surface of DNA. Similar effect was observed when Pd/Al2O3 was treated with Hg(0) [66]. The activity of the solution remaining after separation of Pd/DNA from the reaction mixture was also studied. Thus, the aminocarbonylation reaction of 4-iodotoluene with aniline catalyzed by Pd/DNA was stopped after 1 h, and the reaction solution was subjected to hot filtration through Celite. The as-obtained filtrate was next re-heated for 5 h at 80 °C. After that time the 1H NMR analysis showed 27% yield of desired product, which was comparable to that obtained after 1 h of the standard reaction (18%) and significantly lower than that noted after 6 h (78%). This result indicated on a dominance of the heterogeneous reaction pathway, in agreement with the good recyclability of Pd/DNA. 3.9 Plausible aminocarbonylation mechanism On the basis of the obtained results, we proposed a possible reaction mechanism for the aminocarbonylation reaction via a heterogeneous pathway (Fig. 11 ). Firstly, the oxidative addition of aryl iodide to DNA-supported Pd NPs resulted in the formation of aryl palladium complex A. Then, the migratory insertion of CO generated acyl intermediate B. The nucleophilic attack of amine on the acyl intermediate gave the final amide product. 4 Conclusions A DNA-supported palladium catalyst, Pd/DNA, was prepared cheap natural DNA under mild conditions in an EtOH/H2O solution, without any additional reducing agent. The Pd/DNA catalyst showed good stability. It was recycled five times in the aminocarbonylation reaction with satisfactory results. Its high efficiency in aminocarbonylation with aniline derivatives led to the selective production of substituted benzamides. Under optimized conditions very good results were obtained with primary amines, while secondary amines gave lower yields of the relevant amides. Pd/DNA presented a high ability to activate CO to form carbonylated products, amides, or benzoic acids. The ability of DNA to interact with palladium complexes and small molecules was evidenced [67,68]. Such non-covalent interactions could also influence the reaction course in the catalytic reactions studied in this work. Very good results were also obtained with Mo(CO)6 used as a CO source. In some reactions synergistic effect was observed, leading to an increase in the yield of the desired amide in the presence of CO and Mo(CO)6. This can be explained by the bonding of Mo(CO)6 to the DNA matrix facilitating bimetallic interaction. Our results can be reproduced with samples containing DNA defined in Electronic Supplementary information (see ESI, p1). However, for now, the question of generalizability remains unsolved because different results can be probably obtained using other kind of DNA. It would be useful to test DNA purchased from different manufacturers. This article is piloting the issue and we plan to return to the question of generalizability in our further research. coredata.dc:description: A Pd/DNA catalyst was prepared using Pd(OAc)2 and salmon fish sperm DNA in a H2O/EtOH solution. This catalyst contained Pd(II) coordinated to DNA and ca. 20% of Pd(0) nanoparticles. For the first time, Pd/DNA was applied with very good results in the aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene with different amines in water at 1 atm of CO and with Mo(CO)6 as a CO source. During the catalytic process, Pd(II) was reduced to catalytically active Pd(0), as evidenced by XPS. The aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene with n-hexylamine performed with Mo(CO)6 proceeded with better selectivity than with gaseous CO. Very good results were also obtained with other primary amines, while secondary amines gave a lower yield of the relevant amides. The recovered Pd/DNA catalyst was used in four subsequent runs with high activity.
coredata.dc:title: Pd/DNA as a highly active and recyclable catalyst for aminocarbonylation and hydroxycarbonylation in water: The effect of Mo(CO)6 on the reaction course
